title: NIMH Director Joins Google to Lead Mental Health Research
text:
NIMH Director Joins Google to Lead Mental Health Research Tue, 09/15/2015 - 4:21pm Get today's life science headlines and news - Sign up now! 
Dr.Thomas Insel, the director of the U.S. National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) for the past 13 years, is joining the life sciences division of Google. 
Google Life Sciences is working on a number of projects that can improve different facets of health, such as managing diabetes or possibly, curing cancer. 
Jacquelyn Miller, a spokesperson for Google Life Sciences, told The Verge Insel “is coming on board to explore how the Life Sciences team at Google could have an impact on the huge challenges related to understanding, diagnosing, and treating mental illness.” 
Insel will work with the company to pinpoint which projects they should pursue in behavioral health, and then take charge of those projects. 
Insel is a brain scientist who became well known for studying the biology of attraction and pair bonding, writes The New York Times. He directed funding toward severe mental disorders like schizophrenia, and into basic biological research. 
READ MORE: Google Partners with Ancestry.com to Study Aging 
A letter from the National Institutes of Health (NIH) listed some of Insel’s greatest accomplishments during his tenure at NIMH. 
He launched initiatives like the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium and the Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) effort . The first involves over 500 researchers conducting genetic analyses of mental health issues and the second is “developing a new taxonomy for mental illness research,” according to the letter. 
Insel will officially step down from his position of NIMH director in November. His official start date at Google is unknown. Topics
